Bringing a beloved franchise out of near complete dormancy, The Peanuts Movie has the right amount of charm and humor for children, their parents, and yes, even their grandparents. (Charlie Brown is HOW old?!) This latest take on the comic strip turned cartoon utilizes a brisk pace and a 3-D animation style that cleverly appears to be a hybrid between hand drawn animation and modern digital trickery. It's not, but the presentation almost fooled me. The plot doesn't take us in any new directions, but it doesn't need to. The movie packs in as many references to the Peanuts franchise as it can, sending Charlie Brown on a mad quest to impress a certain redhead, and showcasing that Snoopy and Woodstock still win at life. The older films exuded a somewhat morose and somber feel that centered on lonely children and their experiences with failure. The Peanuts Movie largely ditches that for a more cheerful experience that succeeds in actually allowing that blockhead Charlie Brown to grow as a character and have an arc. I personally despised the placement of modern music in a Peanuts movie, and a lot of the slapstick humor could have been left on the cutting room floor. But whatever. It's a well-crafted children's movie that will probably best serve as a rental or a purchase for long-time fans of these near timeless characters.
This movie captures the heart and soul of the Peanuts gang. I loved this film. I wish I could bring it home on Blu Ray today!

Peanuts was fantastic. I feared that 3D rendition of everyone's' holiday favourite may ruin it. however they used it well. It stayed true to Schultz's style; it kept our animation heritage of adults one can't understand etc. The fight scenes of the red Barron where particularly good. This us also the first film I remember holding Zebedee's attention for the whole duration. highly recommended
See with kids, grandkids, grown kids.

No, The Peanuts Movie doesn't reinvent the wheel. It doesn't add anything to The Peanuts that we haven't seen before. Rather, it is a celebration of what we love so much about these stories: the unforgettable characters, the story situations which have become a staple of The Peanuts, the excellent humor, and the innocent joyfulness. The Peanuts Movie captures this, and therefore is an amazing celebration of what made Charles Schulz's work so amazing. It's an example of simplicity being a good thing, and the sweet, innocent nature of it makes it maybe not the best movie of the year, but certainly one of the most delightful ones of the year. If you even mildly enjoy The Peanuts, this is a movie you're going to want to see.

This is an absolutely perfect Peanuts movie.The computer animation was so beautifully done that I often forgot that I wasn't watching the work of the original animators. The voice talent capture the characters better than any since the original 60's actors. And, the story was everything you could hope for.If I could give it six stars, I would.

Despite the cynicism with which I walk into most movies targeted to my kids, I was surprised by The Peanuts Movie. At a time when visual gags and high-paced action seem to be the preferred route to a child's brain, this movie takes the opposite path. It is thoughtful, entertaining, and definitely satisfying on many levels. On top of that, both my 7-year-old and my 4-year-old thoroughly enjoyed it (and sat through the whole thing...that's saying something for the 4-year-old!!).It retains much of the original charm of the comic strip and various peanuts specials while also providing something better. The animation is smart, clean, and yet it's created in such a way that it feels almost like it was hand-drawn. And the story neatly fits the most memorable pieces of the comic strip into a modest length movie (little read-headed girl, the Red Baron, various character pieces)... AND makes it fit nicely together. They offset each other so that a 90-minute Peanuts film which COULD have been a disaster become not just palatable, but enjoyable.The three of us loved this movie. I highly recommend it!
Unless you crave Charlie Brown and like it as a classic, this movie is maybe a prime time special but not Cinema worthy. Disappointed.
True to the original characters in every way. A delightful story line with a laugh a minute. Just a great movie.

Cute, nostalgic, and fun family entertainment. It's funny to watch as an adult in the 21st century because it really has an 80s feel (they use phones with cords and typewriters). I also kept wondering where everyone's parents were hiding out. :) In any case, the movie made me laugh and smile and was an enjoyable diversion on a rainy Sunday afternoon. The bar keeps getting raised for animation as cartoon characters become ever more life like. This time we've moved onto sophisticated 3D for Charlie Brown. We can all identify with the characters pathos, forever the trier, this time he's hopelessly in love with the new red headed girl in the neighbourhood. There is so much to enjoy here, interspliced with Charlie Brown's story, we have a concurrent storyline with Snoopy and Woodstock fighting the Red Baron. The kids will not be bored, and it's pretty entertaining for adults too. .

Refreshingly old-fashioned. Keeps to the spirit of the original comics and TV specials. I don't get the criticisms that say the characters were ruined. It is a simple story with a sweet message. The most amazing thing is they refrained from "modernizing" it with inappropriate humor like so many kids' movies do today. There was a lot of laughter from little ones in the theater without resorting to fart jokes or winking adult humor. There were typewriters and phones with cords on them. Bi-planes and baseball.The moral was easy to grasp and can actually teach a kid something about personal character.

What a great flick. This film is applicable to various age groups. The characters stay true and there's a good moral to it. Although some parts may be a bit cheesy, Snoopy and his pals still bring the laughs and the "awwwws..."

I honestly never thought I'd see this. A full length theatrical film of Charlie Brown, Snoopy, and the rest of the Peanuts characters 15 years after the passing of creator Charles Schultz. I also didn't think I'd ever see a studio dare use 3D computer animation over the traditional hand drawn comic strip style. And I didn't think it would be as good as it ultimately did.I'm a huge Peanuts fan, ever since I first saw the famous Christmas special when I was around four years old. The varied personalities and laid back relatable stories set it apart from most cartoons I watched back then. Many feared a new CG film would change the tone of what the franchise was (like what has happened with The Smurfs) and thankfully those justifiable fears have been put to rest because this is as pure a Charlie Brown story as I could have hoped for.One can call this a Peanuts greatest hits collection and they'd be right, but that isn't a weakness of the film. Much like several Peanuts specials I've seen before, this film takes many popular gags from the comic strip and put them together as part of a bigger main story. The main story here is Charlie Brown trying to get the attention of the little red haired girl who just moved in next door to him and prove that he is a true winner. But of course poor Charlie Brown always has the worst luck. What I loved seeing was that Charlie always seems to come up short, but it's not due to contrived circumstance, reckless thinking, or an antagonist getting in his way. A lot of time it's from Charlie just being a good person and doing what he feels is the right thing at the cost of him gaining any popularity. One scene involving his sister, Sally, got me rather chocked up.But wait! Snoopy has his own story going on. Or more like his own fantasies. While he is helping Charlie with his struggles with the new girl, Snoopy takes those situations and applies them to a romance novel he's writing that showcases him as World War 1 fighter pilot hero, The Flying Ace, trying to win the affection of a fellow pilot named Fifi and finally taking down his arch nemesis, The Red Baron. The Flying Ace scenes are really fun albeit a bit overused. Would have like to see more of the supporting kid characters interact and trim down the Red Baron stuff a little. And the animation in this movie is totally hypnotic. I've seen it twice and I just want to watch it again just for the animation style alone. It is 3D computer animation, but it still feels like the old cartoons. The frame rate is lowered to give a more 2D flow and the facial expressions have a strong hand drawn style. It's new yet very familiar. There isn't any other animated film that looks quite like it. Even the music is mostly faithful to the original shorts. Vince Guaraldi's score plays throughout. There a few pop songs in there, but they have the appropriate sound and tone.This is definitely one of the better animated films I've in the past few years and is great way to introduce the kids of today to the Peanuts franchise as well as pleasing older fans like myself. And be sure to stay during the credits.Score: 8.5/10
Actually saw it. What do they mean, "not ambitious"? Charlie Brown finally did something he had never done before, and succeeded! #ignorecriticsearnboxofficeearnings

A sweet and delightful kids movie that even adults can enjoy themselves. One of the best animated movies of the year next to Disney/Pixar's 'Inside Out' and one of the best movies of the year period.

Shulz and his classic characters and it was, almost, everything a "Peanuts movie" needed to be.

This was an incredible movie. I took my daughter and wife to see it and it is a spectacular family movie. We always watch all of the older peanut shows so my daughter loved being able to see one from her time. I would watch it all over again.

Terrible, soulless Peanuts movie. It was wrong in so many ways. First of all, Charles Schultz was always able to carry Peanuts on the storyline and characters alone. This is what gave Peanuts it' charm, in contrast to things like Looney Tunes. The production staff at Blue Sky Pictures however didn't "get" this as cartoonish effects were abused during most of the movie, for example there were way too many "Red Baron" scenes and the total stupidity of the "War and Peace" chase and the "summer vacation" part at the end which were totally overdone. The sets were terrible too. The original Peanuts backgrounds have split level houses, 60s modern furniture and beautifully painted trees. In the 1970s cartoons, the backgrounds and sets are one of the most wonderful inspiring parts of the experience, having surely been drawn by someone with watercolor or architectural rendering skills. The sets in this film lacked all inspiration, with almost no trees, boring houses and ridiculous rolling green fields as if the characters were living on a golf course. The story line was completely unbelievable too. Charles Schultz never insulted our intelligence in the ways this movie did, with sappy sentimentality or events and action that could never take place, for example the school "award ceremony". My recommendation to the movie makers and the public - watch some of the orignal films such as "A Charlie Brown Thanksgiving" (1973), read the original comics, and forget about this film.

The legacy of Charles Schulz's Peanuts characters have lived on for decades. It was only inevitable we'd be seeing a rebirth of the series with computer animation, and it was absolutely perfect. Blue Sky took me by surprise by flawlessly capturing the spirit of the Charlie Brown saga, without taking any advantage of current day reboot tropes like over the top plots and unnecessary innuendos. And the artistic style they've chosen with that somewhat "choppy" 2D look drives it home. Even the writing does the film justice, staying true to the source material with not only the story line, but the scripting as well! The whole movie feels the way a Charlie Brown special should, with the right amount of laughs, and the right amount of truly real moments. These are kids growing up in a very big world, and the film completely gets that. It's a beautiful film, that not only satisfies those who grew up with the gang, but also the newest generation of children, who will find this current adaptation something fascinating, with its colorful cast of timeless characters, and unforgettable lessons in life, no matter how big or small the situations may seem. It's innocence in its purest form, with its ultimate ingredient being integrity, and that's what makes The Peanuts Movie the grade A timeless film it deserve to be. Schulz I'm quite positive would be very proud.
A charming, warm, delightful, and worthy love letter to Schulz

When I first heard of the Peanuts franchise being turned into a CGI animated film by BlueSky studios, I had mix feelings. I am not a big fan of Blue Sky studios since most of there films are knock offs of Dreamworks animated films. I felt that the studio was going to destroy the Peanuts franchise since they are owned by Fox, who previously ruined memorable cartoon franchise like Alvin and the Chipmuck and the upcoming Secrets of NIMH reboot. So I went to see the film with all my relatives on Thanksgiving day and came out of the theater with a smile. The Peanuts Movie is probably the second best animated feature film I have seen this year besides Inside Out. The film managed to say true to its source material without making any pop culture references. They show kids going outside instead of playing on there Apple product, that is something that not animated films would do now theses days. The story is a typical Charlie Brown story that every old or new fans will enjoy and relate to. This kid tries everything he wants to accomplish whether its is test or flying a kite, but always fail; however, he never gives up. This is a perfect role model character for the younger audiences to follow. Snoopy is the comedic relief of the film, but always support Charlie Brown through his struggles of talking to the Little Red Hair girl, who is the love interest of the movie. The Little Red Hair girl is just a character that motivates the main character, which doesn`t give her a lot of personalty. The rest of the character don`t have a lot to do with the movie, but they are still iconic Peanuts characters to see on screen. For example; Lucy is the typical bitch who makes fun of Charlie Brown, Linus is the wise kid who enjoys sucking his thumb and holding his blanket, Sally is the supporting sister, Peppermint Patty and Marcie are the tomboy and bookworm best friend, Schroeder is the musician who enjoys playing his piano and so many more characters that are easily likable. The voice acting in this movie is perform by actual kids and its actually not bad. Another thing I praise about the voice acting is bringing back the old voice recordings of Bill Melendez as Snoopy and Woodstock. The animation is a perfect upgrade to the Peanuts design since it stays true to its source material from the comics and TV specials. If this film was done in 2D animation, I would still enjoy the animation no matter what design that the film is going towards. If there is two problems that the film has to offer is the Snoopy segments. I thought they focus too much on that part of the film instead of the actual movie about Charlie Brown. I would love to see more of the other Peanuts character than the Snoopy flying segments. The other nitpick I have is some of the writing in the film is rehashing the main source material from the Peanuts TV special. I still enjoy the writing, but I think the film use too much of the homage writing deliver to this film. Overall, The Peanuts Movie is a great movie for the whole entire family. Even non-fans could still enjoy this movie. I wish Blue Sky studio could make more original films like the Peanuts movie, but where still stuck to the never ending movie franchise, Ice Age.
Very sweet. Great for kids. Very amusing.

Probably the best animated movie I've seen in years. I love the effect of having high resolution, high frame rate background elements, while using hand drawn elements and limiting the framerate of the characters. It created a very unique look and made the movie feel familiar. The story was well written, and dealt with more mature themes than animated movies typically deal with. The jokes were smart and intellectually stimulating for the adults, while at the same time being visually stimulating for the kids.The sense of humanity and humor in the movie was surprising. This was much better than I hoped. It is a joy and fun. It gets rid of most of the negative that always hate in Peanuts and is hopeful and fun. I really liked how they did running stories inside of the story. Strongly recommended. I saw it only in 2D. Imagine it is better in 3D.

I adored this movie for the very reasons most of the cynical critics are bashing it. There is zero reason to dislike this movie, and I am wondering if the people who disliked it have souls. This was one of my favorite movies of the year, in a year with a few really great movies.
Great message for the little one.

As I sit there watching the recent Peanuts Movie a thought occurs to me: Would I have liked this better if I was younger? While I am writing this review I realize that I as a College age adult I'm really not in the intended age audience for this film but I'll have it be no secret that I still enjoy children's films. I even still love the Charles Schulz Peanuts strips. But as for the Peanuts Movie, I wanted to like it more than I did coming out of it and it is certainly one of those movies where I feel that if you liked it, good for you I totally understand why, but I can say the exact same thing if you told me that you didn't like it. There's certainly enough to like in the film. The gags involving Snoopy and Woodstock are funny, there's some great physical comedy as well, Charlie Brown is his normal, loveable loser self, and the film is visually stunning. Perhaps stunning is an understatement. Every single frame of this movie is done in a sort of CGI approximation of Claymation, but what makes it so pleasing to look at is that every single thing in the movie has remarkable texture work done to it and is modeled to a way that mimics the distinctive Charles Schulz style but in 3D, in fact the film mixes bits of this with actual hand drawn segments that look as if they could have been drawn by Schulz himself. Unfortunately the fact is that the film is amazing to look at, perhaps not so much to watch.For all the laughs I had with the segments involving Snoopy and Woodstock and Charlie Brown, the rest of the film is a series of misadventures and arcs that unfortunately usually follow the same turn of events: something good happens to Charlie Brown and we get hopeful and then something bad happens to him that brings him down again. All these arcs seem to last about 20 minutes or so which makes the film seem like a compilation of a TV show that I never watched. In fact if I didn't know any better I might guess that it might have been the original idea or might be the idea for this film to serve as the pilot for a new Peanuts TV show. It certainly feels like an origin story at times, what with long running gags from the strip getting their setups all at the same time or nearly every single one of the film's dozens of characters being addressed by name as they get what feels like their mandatory 20 seconds and lines in. It's not a totally irredeemable story, just one that kind of feels like a rushed first draft.I don't want to spoil the ending too much but all I'll say is that, as strange as it may seem to say this, it doesn't feel like Charlie Brown should get the happy ending he gets in this film. This is not because he's a bad person, in fact he's a very good person in the movie. It's more because of how out of line from the way that the movie treats him as the butt of jokes and having all his hopes and dreams crushed throughout the movie. Plus at times it seemed like the movie was trying to make me believe that some other ending was going to happen and I was actually kind of looking forward to that, but after a while I had to accept that the movie was going to go in the direction it was going.But even beside the story problems there are still plenty of questionable decisions from the filmmakers that leave me scratching my head. The aforementioned visual style is great but some of the animation alternates between fluid animation and this near stop motion and it takes me out of the movie for a second with how jarring it is. It's kind of like when you're playing a video game and suddenly the framerate dips due to too much activity. This may very well have been a problem with the digital print of the movie or the theater itself but it would not shock me to find out this is the same in every print. Then there are the other questionable decisions, like the extremely questionable one to add contemporary music to a film that if not for these bits of the soundtrack would seem like a period piece set in the 1950s or whatever timeless period that the long running comic strip was set in. Another questionable one was to have so many gags and jokes be repeated verbatim from the numerous comics, TV shows, movies, specials, etc. that make up the long running Peanuts franchise. When I paid money to see the Peanuts Movie I was kind of under the impression that I would be seeing a movie in the style of the Peanuts franchise, not the Peanuts franchise in movie form.I do realize that this may make it sound as if I thought it was a bad film when that really isn't the case. I can't really say that I liked the film and I can certainly think of more things that I didn't like about it than otherwise, but I wouldn't call it a bad film. I'd more or less call it a mixed bag of a film. It's charming enough and it's funny at a lot of times but it's a movie with plenty of questionable decisions that don't really pay off as well as the filmmakers thought they would. I will say this though: If you have kids in your family take them to see it because they will love it, and I do realize that you can say that about just about any film for kids but this is a really good film for the kids to watch because it's charming and funny and loveable enough at times that it really does feel like it belongs as a part of the Peanuts library. Perhaps, it might be sad to say, I'm just too old for it.6/10
Very sweet and very nostalgic.

I am struggling to find words to describe how enjoyable this movie was to enjoy with my child. A tear came to my eye as I watched the intrigue and delight my daughter experienced while watching Snoopy pursue the Red Baron and Charlie Brown overcome his seemingly endless obstacles. The Peanuts Movie is a rare gem, offering meaningful insights learned vicariously through the innocent and comical Charlie Brown and his pal Snoopy . The movie never comes across heavy-handed; it remains wonderfully light, nostalgic and wholesomely entertaining for the fans of yesteryear and the children of today. A rare five start review from this humble moviegoer. SJJ, 11/24/15
One of the best Animated films of 2015.
You better have a nostalgic tie to this movie to make it through. Unbearably dull for myself and my daughter. The longest hour and a half I've spent in a theater in a long time.
I loved it, but, in fairness, I'm a huge Peanuts fan - and they did the gang justice!

I went into the movie expecting it to be okay, but I found it to be a very funny and endearing movie with lots of quick humor and an amazing amount of respect to the original material. Those who have grown up with the holiday shows will recognize a lot of aspects that were borrowed directly from "A Charlie Brown Christmas". The movie also throws a lot of references back to the comic strips that would be missed by those who only watch the holiday specials.Those who fear that this will be a cheap attempt at a money grab should be very, very pleased. Yes, it is a lot of what we know with nothing particularly new; but the presentation makes it worthwhile. The movie pays a lot of reverence and respect to the original material to the point that my entire family - even my teenage daughter - loved it. I truly believe that Charles Schulz would be very pleased with "The Peanuts Movie".

Despite the story being a tad bit unfocused, The Peanuts Movie is a charming throwback to the days where Charles Schulz was still making Peanuts strips, as well as an excellent way to introduce The Peanuts to a new generation

It's thin on plot, but immensely high on nostalgia, charm, and respect for the original comics and TV specials. The Peanuts Movie caused a stupid smile to spread across my face for the entire runtime, and I wouldn't have it any other way.

Growing up, I was a huge Peanuts fan. I watched all of the holiday specials at least once a year and used to enjoy reading the old comic strips. So, I was nervous to see how Blue Sky Studios would handle this classic brand. It could have gone one of two ways. It could have been a funny and sweet rendition that pays homage to the original comics and TV specials. On the other hand, it could have been a CGI-washed mess made to make money off of a well known brand. Luckily, it falls into the first category!The Peanuts Movie was like a full-length Peanuts special. There's not real story or character development. It was many skits around a single general idea strung together. However, it worked very well! Though clich�d and predictable, the story is always fun and often hilarious!The writing is fantastic. I found myself laughing at the dialogue and the classic slap-stick comedy. All of the Peanuts characters are just as you remember them! I also really enjoyed the extremely fast pace. The animation is utterly gorgeous. It was a mix of the classic 2D Charlie Brown style with a modern twist! It blended the CGI with actual 2D animation seamlessly! My only flaws with The Peanuts Movie were in the story. Though it was fun, I wasn't completely invested in anything that was going on. I understand that it was a "kids movie", but it was like watching many classic Charlie Brown 10-minute specials back to back. Overall, The Peanuts Movie is a hilarious, beautifully animated and very sweet film that pays homage to Shultz's original brand. See it!
Anyone can relate to the great aspects of The Peanuts Movie, thanks to its' bright source material, heartwarming comedy, and incredible animation.

Full disclosure. I'm 61 yrs. old and lived for all things Peanuts when I was a kid. When I had a child, I instilled the tradition of Peanuts with my daughter. We religiously watched "It's the Great Pumpkin, Charlie Brown" as well as the famous Peanuts Christmas special every single year. I anxiously awaited this new movie and was not disappointed. I enjoyed the Snoopy segments the most and shed a tear at the last scene. It dragged a little tiny bit in the middle, but overall it was a fine tribute to Charles Schulz, a true genius.
It was charming and modest. It was very true to the original films which, for me, made it a bit boring.

I didn't grow up on Peanuts, this is the first time I've been introduced to these characters and I was underwhelmed. It was a cute movie, the characters are fun, there were some good laughs and Snoopy was awesome. I had reservations about this "reboot", if you will, of the Peanuts franchise, but I shouldn't have been so skeptical. They've done a fine job bringing the world of "good old Charlie Brown" and company into modern-day animation. There's a lot of familiarity for long-time fans - the original Vince Guaraldi theme music, the characters, how Charlie Brown's musings are depicted like the line drawings of the original daily comic strip. Some of the jokes are familiar too, but I attribute that more to homage then to lack of originality. I love some of the updating of the sly humor that marked the best of Schulz's classic work, like when Lucy discusses with Charlie Brown how he can be more attractive to girls and asks him, "Do you have a diversified portfolio?" Snoopy's antics are just as amusing as always, though I thought the parallel storyline of his romance with "Fifi" took up a little too much of the movie. Also, the main storyline of Charlie Brown's struggles to make his feelings known to the "little red-haired girl" is a little too familiar. Still, there's an awful lot to like about this movie, which is very family friendly (we took our two-year-old granddaughter as her first movie theater experience - she loved it) and respectful to the history and traditions of the Peanuts universe.

It is one of the best animated films of the year and it just might have the best computer animation I've ever seen.

The Peanuts MovieInitial Reaction: A documentary about nuts?Main Characters Charlie Brown, Lucy van Pelt, Linus Van Pelt, Sally Brown, Schroeder: Some of the kids featured in the comic. They are voiced by Noah Schnapp, Hadley Belle Miller, Alexander Garfin, Mariel Sheets, and Noah Johnston.Plost Summary It is wintertime, and the kids are getting ready for the holidays (that is after they get through the school year before that). Charlie Brown is trying his best to be a "winner", but every time he does something like pitch a baseball or go skating, it all goes wrong. And when a really cute redheaded girl moves in next door, Charlie Brown gets a big time crush on her. But he's too shy to ask her out - and he thinks she wouldn't go with him because he's not a "winner." Still, his dog, Snoppy, tries his best to get him to overcome his shyness. And there are a few events - like a dance and a assembly meeting - where Charlie Brown can show that he really is someone special.SCORINGMain Characters The makers of the film follow the comic book and the TV specials to a T. They show off all the quirkiness of Charlie Brown, his family and his classmates. We get to bossy Lucy, the musical Schroeder and the boy who just can't catch a break, Charlie Brown. SCORE: 9Supporting Cast The rest of the gang is just as memorable as they were in the TV shows/comic strip. This is probably the only time I want to hear some nonsensical mumbling from the adults. SCORE: 9Plot This film has a great start, but it feels like a run on sentence. First something happens, then we get another event, followed by another event - with not much development of character And the sub plot about Snoopy's fighter pilot double fighting off the Red Baron was fun, but it dragged on a bit. SCORE: 7Originality If you've seen the comic or the TV shows, then you're in for a treat - this film will be familiar to you. If not, then this film still can be fun to watch - even if it visits themes that have been done in other films with kids going to school. SCORE: 7Violence Factor The only really scary parts are with Snoopy's fighting ace pilot. He gets into dogfights with invisible enemies, and gets shot down. But how does he walk away from such a crash? SCORE: 7Other Moral Issues This film has a innocent crush at the center of it - and it stays innocent. And it does a very good job of showing what actually makes for a decent person. SCORE: 9Final Score (out of 60): 48 % Score: 80%It may have a story that goes on for too long, but the Peanuts gang shows us why they are still entertaining even after all these years.

Brilliantly re-introducing the legendary Peanuts gallery to a whole new generation of Lucies and Linuses, this touching colorful Movie smartly doesn't throw out the Brown with the bath water. Instead of going cynical and cutting edge, the latest adventures of Charlie and Snoopy perfectly nail the heart and humor of Charles Schultz, connecting with nostalgia as if it were the football that our pint-size hero finally gets to kick. Indeed, The Peanuts Movie ends up to be the furthest thing from a "dark and stormy night." In this G-rated animated family flick, Snoopy embarks upon his greatest mission as he takes to the skies to pursue their arch-nemesis, while his best pal Charlie Brown begins his own epic quest back home. In an era when potty humor, fully automatic zingers, and overly syrupy messages get fired at the audience from characters moving faster than Ricochet Rabbit on a cocaine binge, it says a lot that this flick plays out nice and easily as opposed to fast and furiously. This is not to say that it's slow-just that it's not overactive and frenetic like the Ice Age series that ironically comes courtesy of the same inspired minds and animation house. Seriously, if select children want that badly for racecar-in-the-red bedlam, they need Ritalin-not Scrat, the Flying Prehistoric Squirrel. Certainly, Peanuts doesn't lack ambition, it simply fixes up - rather than outright fixes - what isn't broke. With eye-popping computer animation, the movie brings in all of the telltale Schultz hallmarks that made the comic strips and holiday specials (A Charlie Brown Christmas and It's the Great Pumpkin, Charlie Brown) so enjoyable and indelible. Some slight modern touches (Meghan Trainor sings "Better When I'm Dancin") don't do much for the story but they don't exactly detract either. Bottom line: New Kids on the Blockhead

Nearly 65 years ago, artist Charles M. Schulz created a comic strip called 'Peanuts' that has endured through many generations. Sadly, Schultz has passed to not see 'Peanuts' enter the new millennium, and develop into the modern era of animation. Now, with the help of Blue Sky Studios, the wide cast of characters from 'Peanuts' make a return to theaters in a new movie called "The Peanuts Movie". Featuring characters like Charlie Brown, Lucy, Linus, Schroeder, Snoopy and more, the film does a magnificent job at recreating its comic origins, as well as maintaining the simplistic charm that defined it. "The Peanuts Movie" is a fantastic adaptation of familiar characters with modern animation to showcase the process of how charming and memorable time as made them.The story has Charlie Brown (Noah Schnapp) trying to impress The Little Red-Haired Girl (Francesca Capaldi), even though he does not have the complete social skills to talk to her. Charlie Brown does his best to win her heart, but to no avail, unfortunately. With the help of his trustful dog Snoopy (Bill Melendez archives), Charlie Brown must discover who he truly is, and find out what it means to stand up for yourself."The Peanuts Movie" is a brilliant representation of the works that Schulz did. The characters are the ones everyone knows and loves, and they are represented well here. Charlie Brown is the lovable loser, Lucy is the bossy one, Linus is the supportive friend, Snoopy is the loyal dog companion, and so on. The music has a nice tone to the sweet nature that the comic strips provided, and even includes a few selections from some of the specials that 'Peanuts' have done- most notably, "A Charlie Brown Christmas" bringing up some familiar tunes. But really makes the film worth the price of admission is the story, and the animation.Let's start with the animation. Blue Sky Studios has been known for a more realistic cartoonish style when it comes to their movies. But with "The Peanuts Movie", co-writers and producers Craig and Bryan Schulz- the son and grandson of Charles Schultz- working on this movie, we have gotten a very memorable animated film. The art style mimics that of Schulz, and even though the movie is done in CGI, it almost looks like a 2D animated film. The talented team behind this movie definitely deserves praise as they did an outstanding job recreating the style of the work of Schulz.Now, let's move on to the story. The story provided in the movie is simplistic in nature, and in spirit to what the 'Peanuts' comic strip was all about: providing the inside outlook in the mind of a child. Plus, the movie has a simple lesson that kids would understand very easily. This is a good story for an otherwise great movie.There is, however, one minor problem with the story, and that is wishing for a little more sarcastic humor that the comic strip was best known for.Good grief, that was a lot! But in conclusion, "The Peanuts Movie" wonderfully brings to life the charm and simplistic greatness that Charles M. Schulz provided in his comic strips nearly all those years ago, and this is proof that the legacy has continued. Welcome back Charlie Brown, we've missed you.
oh my gosh. too adorable. so many feelings. my only complaint was that there wasn't enough of the other characters, Lucy, Linus, Schroder, I would have liked to see a few more scenes with them.

This movie is just plain adorable. It completely and perfectly captures the feel of the classic Peanuts gang in every way. Every frame feels familiar, while managing to feel original. I'm very pleased that they didn't feel the need to "update" it for modern audiences. There's no computers or cell phones. Schroder hasn't given up his classical music for hip-hop. Charlie Brown gets tangled up in his phone cord. There's no jokes about Marcy and Peppermint Patty being a lesbian couple. This is classic Peanuts as it's always been and always should be. Unfortunately, for all its classic charm, it also falls a little short on the humor, at least from an adult point of view. It has a few chuckle-out-loud moments, but for the most part, it's "cute" more than "funny." Snoopy's Flying Ace sequences are, by far, the best part of the movie. It actually sort of gets a little dull in places.Overall, THE PEANUTS MOVIE is something that I think Charles Schulz would have been proud of. Blue Sky did a superb job paying homage to an American icon and my hat goes off to them for the effort. Well done, folks. THE PEANUTS MOVIE gets a "See With Your Kids, or Netflix It" on Talon's Movie Scale.

The Peanuts Movie is one of my favourite movies I have seen all year. Everything in the movie works and it works exceptionally. It is such a joy to see all the characters on the big screen. There's a really great moment in the beginning, they're all skating and they're in a line and the camera pans by each of them. It's a sort of curtain call as you are reintroduced to each character. All the voice work is terrific. Whoever voiced Linus did a very good job at capturing his voice and his spirit.The scenes with Snoopy are all great. What I love is that it's still the original voice. The man who voiced Snoopy has passed away, but they went and got archived recordings and used them in this movie. Snoopy is always one of the highlights of the Peanuts specials and it's no different here. Every scene he is in he steals. However, the best part of the movie, is the charm it has. The heart. The movie is guaranteed to keep you smiling from beginning to end. There's a real innocence throughout the entire movie and it's so refreshing to see a simple movie that teaches kids great lessons. There's a point in the movie where Charlie Brown is faced with a choice, he could lie and be seen as something he's not, or be honest and lose his sudden popularity and he chooses to be honest, he doesn't even question it! It's so refreshing to see a movie where the character doesn't even question his integrity. The ending of the movie is as perfect as you can get. It tugs at your heart strings and is a perfect example of what the Peanuts is all about. The Peanuts Movie is great for kids and Adults alike. It's a great tribute to the past Peanuts specials we've all seen countless times. It's heartwarming and teaches kids great lessons. It's one of the best movies of the year. If you have not seen it yet, you are doing yourself a disservice. Get out there right now and treat yourself to a wonderful movie.

THE PEANUTS MOVIE -- fun and charming all the way! I saw this film in a theatre filled with little kids who laughed at all of Charlie Brown's failed attempts to gain acceptance by his peers and the attention of the new girl. I'm not a kid, so my adult mind can only guess why Charlie Brown's adventures with insecurity are timeless. Well, Charlie Brown tries hard, and fails every time. The whole world seems to conspire against him, but his honesty and genuine heart makes him a star at the end. We also get to experience the world of Snoopy who is everything we all wish we could be -- talented, creative, funny, and cool. Kids in the audience kept asking their parents about what was going on with Snoopy and his imaginary aerial battles, but they kept laughing along with Charlie Brown the whole time. I think that speaks volumes on what kids relate to... All of us have lived through many mistakes so we totally get Charlie Brown -- we can laugh at ourselves. With Snoopy, he's the adult who knows the answer to everything and can do everything we can't do... Anyway, that's my armchair psychology take on Peanuts. I want the Great Pumpkin story next, please!

A fantastic family movie that captures the feel and meaning behind Charles M. Schulz's Peanuts comics. The movie centers around Charlie Brown (Noah Schnapp) a kid who just can't catch a break. He's a klutz, he cant fly a kite, he can't play baseball, people consistently make fun of him, etc. Charlie Brown feels a lone in the world, but one day something amazing happens. A new girl with red hair (Francesca Capaldi) moves into town and Charlie Brown see's this as an opportunity to start fresh with someone. Along with his best friend and dog Snoopy (Bill Melendez) Charlie Brown starts to make a new him, but along the way he realizes there's more things important like being yourself that really do matter all along! The Peanuts are a rightfully beloved American fable that have permeated the culture so deeply that one needs not to have ever read a single strip to know of and adore the ill-fated antics of Charlie Brown, his over-achieving dog Snoopy, and their childish gang. The Peanuts Movie is a film version of a smile, capturing with such reverence what we as culture have always loved about Schultz's creation. At its worst moments, it's a passable nostalgia trip for families to take together. At its best, however, it's a cute and gently funny little-kids film with strong morals and a giant heart. It plays very much like a compilation of the daily comic strips strung together by a somewhat loose narrative of Charlie Brown trying to impress the ever allusive Little Red-Haired Girl. It's magically fun spending time in this world, free of adult cynicism, focusing instead on Charlie Brown's own good-natured and childish neuroses. His predictable but sweet arc is like a first coming-of-age story for preshoolers. Each of the other main Peanuts (Snoopy, Linus, Lucy, Peppermint Patty, Schroeder, Pigpen, etc) get their moments, all appropriately charming and faithful.All of this is animated with beauty and such respect for its own history. That respect, at times, is the main real downfall of the whole, at times retreading and calling-back some of the classic jokes and references we all know in a somewhat clumsy way (Does Linus really have to talk about the Great Pumpkin so out of context?). Mostly, though, Peanuts is a truly funny all-ages romp that refreshingly never resorts to cheap innuendos to keep parents engaged. Timeless and absolutely adorable.

Charlie Brown is always in the wrong place at the wrong time and you get exactly that from this film. The music is there, this time from one of my favorite composers, Christophe Beck. Beck did a great job at setting the mood with the wonderfully simple piano theme.Comparing this to another animated film this year that was aimed towards kid, The Spongebob Squarepants film, The Peanutes Movie outweighs in it every category. It's a smart, sweet, and relatively simple story line that never tries to outreach it's grasp. Plus, this is the perfect time of year for this movie to come out. I think my only complaint would be that the red baron sequences didn't fit as well into the story as I think the writers were hoping. But the animation is surprisingly fantastic, the characters are exactly who they should be, and the story has a really heartwarming touch to it.7.6/10

I attended a special screening of this film for Brooks Institute's 70th anniversary, and of whom 2 of the screenwriters attended Brooks (B. Schultz and C. Uliano). I'm so glad I was able to see the film because as a kid growing up in the 70's I would spend hours in the library floor reading the Peanuts strip compilation books. Taking my 2 young girls with me I explained to them what to expect and although they knew little of the characters, I believe they've learned a part of myself and my childhood, reading the Sunday funnies at the dining room table, and getting that warm fuzzy feeling of having a warm puppy laying at the foot of your bed. So yes, this film is a cross-generational heart warming and funny film, and although it's nothing new in terms of what my generation has already seen, the film creates a bond for the kids of today to the values and lessons of the past.

The Peanuts Movie, for any fan of the world famous comic strip drawn by Charles M. Schulz, is a nostalgic trip down memory lane with plenty of old references and charms to bring a smile throughout 92 minutes.For younger audiences not familiar with Peanuts, this movie can definitely serve as a good introduction. In the first few minutes you can get a good sense of who these characters are and how the interact with certain people.For the older fans, this movie will definitely be a treat. For anyone worried that the 3D animation is too modern, I say that not only does it stay faithful to the original look and feel to the classic animated specials, but it is able to take advantage of the medium in different kinds of ways. This is not a film that is animated like modern 3D animated films; you can tell that they definitely took extra care in the handling of the story, animation, and visual appearance. Within the first moments of the film, I was already getting feelings of nostalgia from all the memories of growing up with Peanuts, and I felt that way constantly throughout the film. The characters is what everyone remembers Peanuts by, and Blue Sky does a very good job of capturing each one's personalities; even most of the voices sound similar to the ones I remember growing up with from "A Charlie Brown Christmas." You can tell Blue Sky took extra care to make sure this film could retain the timeless quality that Peanuts establishes; there are no modern-day references, no rap music, and the kids still write with pencils on paper!Christophe Beck does a fine job for the film's score, which mostly comprises of original score, old favorites from Vince Guaraldi, and a couple of pop songs. I personally did not have an issue with the pop music and felt they did a decent job with the flow of the film.While a very charming film, there are a few things I would nitpick about, most of which involve Snoopy's imaginary scenes with the Red Baron. While I do like the addition of these sequences that coincide with Charlie Brown's story, I felt some parts (especially towards the end) tended to drag on for a bit. I feel the last couple of sequences could have been trimmed down, and the parts where Snoopy is cutting between imagination and reality in other kid's houses, while funny, did not need as many as it did.While the film does not break any extreme new ground, it was definitely a treat to watch. I was smiling from beginning to end just from memories. I recommend this film to anyone that is a Peanuts fan.

Charles Schulz would be proud of this effort. Charlie Brown and crew were likable and funny even to those who didn't grow up with them. Dialogue was quite good compared to some of the other Blue Sky animated movies where it has been God-awful. The Snoopy & Woodstock segments showcased the digital effects nicely. I highly recommend Peanuts as a feelgood family movie.
one of the best animation films of the year easy. Beautiful message and stays true to itself

From the studio that brought us the Ice Age franchise comes a movie that is very long overdue: The Peanuts Movie. This film serves as a love letter to Charles Schulz and delivers some of the best family fun you will find at the movies. This movie is filled to the brim with everything that made us love these characters to start with and best of all, this movie gets (mostly) everything right. The best part of this film is the animation itself. This movie is absolutely gorgeous to look at. The animation style is computer generated but is made in the style of Schulz's drawings of the characters. IN fact, there are certain snippets of footage in this film that are indeed 2D hand drawn animation that make this movie feel like a homecoming rather than a reboot. There are times in this movie where you simply feel like you are watching a classic Peanuts movie that came out years ago and it is definitely thanks to the effort behind the visuals of this movie. The writing is also a major player in this because the writers here remembered their target audience and that being everyone. We get good and clean family fun in this movie. So many adaptations of older properties feel the need to include raunchy humor for the adults but here the team remembered that this is the Peanuts crew and let the comedy speak for itself. The comedy here is a mix between hilarious slapstick humor as well as well written gags that will appeal to both children as well as adults. This jokes for the adults are blatant, but they are so quick and subtle that they add to the charm of this film. In classic Peanut's fashion there is a message in this film that isn't hammered in, but is shown through truly heartfelt moments. It is very much worth mentioning that the use of the characters is handled superbly with each character getting their due. Charlie Brown is still lovable, Lucy is as harsh as ever, Linus is still Linus, and Snoopy and Woodstock steal the show like never before. The story this time around is simple but effective with Charlie Brown falling for the new girl in class and he is trying his best to impress her. Now this is where my criticism comes in. The story works, there is no doubt about that, however i feel like they could have done more with it. What we have is phenomenal but i feel that the ending is too rushed and if the film had been longer it would have benefitted from it. Other than that one criticism, I loved this movie from start to finish. The heartfelt moments hit hard, the comedy hits harder, and most importantly these are the Peanuts that we know and love. The story could be longer and handled better at the end, but at the end of the day The Peanuts Movie is well worth your time. Take the family out to see this one, I guarantee you will have a good time.

The plot is Charlie Brown falls head over heels for the red-haired girl who lives next door and is also the newest classmate. What can be tiring is the running gag that everything Charlie does or attempts falls apart, but Charlie can always be counted on to do the right thing when it amounts to character. Also, there is too much Snoopy, too many fantasy Red Baron fight scenes. Best part is when Charlie goes to Lucy for psychiatric advice and promptly pays her fee- a nickel.
Definitely one of the most faithful adaptations made in a while.

A phenomenal experience. I've seen all the previous full length Peanuts movies, as well as many of the TV specials, and there are so many references and inside jokes to them that I'm sure even I missed some of them. For those like me that grew up on Charlie Brown, it will be a fantastic nostalgic trip down memory lane. For those who haven't seen as much, the jokes and inside references will still be funny because they all fit perfectly within the narrative of the movie. It's perfect for children and adults, a story about a kid who can't seem to do anything right but still does everything with character and integrity that shows he really is doing it right. Hopefully, just as A Charlie Brown Christmas has been playing for 50 years, this too will entertain audiences for generations to come.

A rare home run in modern animated movies, "The Peanuts Movie" is a delightful breath of fresh air amongst enjoyable but familiar kids movie tales. Unlike almost every animated movie nowadays, this is has no ticking clock, no epic journey and no modern references that pander to the lowest common denominator of movie go-ers. Instead we get a simple and sweet movie about Charlie Brown just trying to fit in, which is a lot more relatable than the other animated movies out there. Just watching Charlie trying to do his best is enduring enough, but with everything else that director Steve Martino and the rest of the crew of this movie add in, just takes it above and beyond. I can't remember the last time a movie started and firmly planted a smile on me that lasted there for the entire running time. Every character feels exactly like their 60's and 70's counterparts, it carry's the spirit of the peanuts so well, I actually can't believe this is real. The animation is probably the best CGI has ever looked, the way they capture the look of both the Peanuts comics and the animated TV specials and the original movies. Also if your a cartoon dork like me, the amount of little easter eggs, in-jokes and references to the Peanuts legacy including the most admirable one, in the original TV specials the director Bill Melendez voiced both Snoopy and Woodstock and for this movie they used only archival voice recordings of Bill Melendez for Snoopy and Woodstock. Overall, "The Peanuts Movie" is a wonderful experience that had me from the first second to the last second.
better than SPECTRE4.5/5
Not much storyline, but quite funny and entertaining. Good enough for the kids.

Easily the best Blue Sky film to date... for the ironic reason that the studio does (almost) no more or less then do justice to Peanuts; the best parts of the film are cut and paste from Shultz's comic. One positive and ironic addition Blue Sky makes is that their normally spastic and exhausting status quo, stripped away out of deference to the vintage, low key tone of Charlie Brown, is to elevate it to above the often monotone delivery of past adaptations.

Steve Martino revisits the characters of Charles M. Schulz in The Peanuts Movie.Running with a very very very friendly tone and a brief 85 minute run-time, the plot comes complete with many nostalgia moments and a delightful story. With that said, even with a shorter run-time than a lot of other films, this one still seems a bit stretched. Growing up on Charles Schulz' Peanuts gang gave me somewhat high expectations for the new movie. Fans of the Peanuts have always loved the relatable characters and the warmth of the themes that resonate throughout each image. So if you're like me, I can guarantee that you won't be disappointed.It's been 35 years since the last theatrical Peanuts film, Bon Voyage, Charlie Brown (and Don't Come Back) hit theaters, and the first since Schultz' death back in 2000. But written by Schultz' son and grandson, it's easy to see that the apple doesn't fall far from the tree. It keeps with the spirit of the original works while bringing a modern animation style. And thankfully, that's about the only contemporary feature that this film has. They do a great job of not modernizing the content too much. It doesn't succumb to fart jokes or modern frivolities. There are no cheap gimmicks to get laughter. It's just a classy adaptation of the classy source material we grew up loving--even featuring echoes of Vince Guaraldi's trademark compositions.The Peanuts Movie revolves around everyone's favorite underdog, Charlie Brown, and his quest to get the new girl to think of him as more than a klutz. He wants her to see him as cool and popular. All the old characters are present here. There's a subplot that is shown interstitially throughout the film featuring Snoopy imagining that he's flying his plane, trying to rescue his love, Fifi, from the Red Baron.It's a simple love story, but that's what Peanuts does so well. They provide us with grandeur lessons through straightforward means. In this case Charlie Brown learns about confidence, being true to himself, and perseverance--lessons that can have just as much impact on the adults watching as it does on their children.What the movie does best is provide so much depth to Charlie Brown's character without straying away from the already established depth that we've known him to have throughout the years. It doesn't try to reinvent the characters for a modern world--it appropriately fits this storyarc into the Peanuts canon without disrupting it. The only time the film slows down is when the Snoopy storyline comes to a close and finishes with a somewhat lengthy finale. The subplot is actually a fun addition to the movie, since each segment only lasts about 45 seconds, but the climax of it all runs for about 4 minutes and slightly takes away from the momentum of the film. However, this is only a minor hiccup in an otherwise fantastic film.The Peanuts Movie truly has an old soul as far as movies go--especially of the family variety. It proves, once again, the timelessness of Schultz' beloved characters.Twizard Rating: 95
Total throwback to the tv specials. Which is why I absolutely loved it.

Only works at evoking nostalgia and adds nothing new to the franchise. It could have been just another episode of The Peanuts on TV. Was very slow to develop and it just felt like something was missing.

What I got to say about "The Peanuts Movie" is that it's a good classic animated movie. "It's heartwarming and will put a smile right on your face." The performances (voice acting) by the whole cast is great. The directing by Steve Martino is good. The screenplay by Brian Schulz, Craig Schulz and Bryan Schulz is good. The cinematography is good. The score in this movie is phenomenal to the highest degree. Finally, the effects are fine. "I'm raving that "The Peanuts Movie" is a movie that is excellent for all age. For my opinion, if your a big fan of the characters in this movie then I say go an see it."

The Peanuts Movie is not meant to be innovative or ambitious, it is nothing more than a nostalgic throwback to the innocent jokes and imaginative adventures from the classic series. Because of this level of simplicity, The Peanuts Movie will resonate with the series fans, however, I doubt it will resonate with many others.Director Steve Martino, who also brought you Ice Age: Continental Drift, manages to recreate the tone of the old series. It is difficult to write about a movie that has such a close resemblance to its origins; not much seems to have changed. In comparison to today's children movies, The Peanuts Movie can seem quite dull at times. In an attempt to make it newer and appealing to the younger audience, the excessive use of mainstream songs throughout the movie becomes unbearable at times, the plot extends for a little too long and Snoopy's separate adventure, while interesting at first, gives the impression of being just a filler to elongate the movie.The animation however, is done beautifully. Watching these classic characters that once appeared in newspapers and old TV's come to life give the viewer a sense of warmth. This feeling accompanies you from beginning to the end, when the film states the moral of the story clearer than any other children's movie has ever done it.While The Peanuts Movie manages to bring back old characters to life and most likely, meet the expectations of old fans, it does not go far beyond that.

I was hoping my three year old daughter would not catch the message within the movie that a boy is judged by his character, while a girl just has to be pretty. But she did. I was talking to her afterward about how CB had good character traits, when I mentioned the girl she said "The pretty one?" and my heart sank.As a college prof, I am glad she is not old enough to catch the message that plagiarism is service.

The Peanuts Movie is Better than Expected!!! It is SO nice and refreshing to have a movie stay true to the original charm, creativity and likability of what made the Peanuts movies so great in the first place. The Muppets "re-creators" need to have a seat in the Peanuts classroom and learn how to do it right - first, stick to the original formula (Coca-Cola learned that lesson the hard way), then add the magic of modern animation (including 3D) with just a touch of new creative, humorous "shtick" to add an unexpected surprise! Also, during these "modern" times where there is a tremendous lack of brotherly love, The Peanuts Movie hits a home run in modeling how to be a true team player. Well done!!! A++ !!!

"The Peanuts Movie" is a movie adaptation of the source material comic strip about a socially awkward boy named Charlie Brown and his many antics with his dog Snoopy and eclectic friends. In the movie adaptation we finally discover the origin of the little red-haired girl, Charlie Brown's crush. She makes an appearance as an actual character, and of course Charlie Brown spends most of the movie figuring out how to impress her. This movie is really about Charlie Brown's quest to find meaning in is life and do something noteworthy. Several of the characters have side tromps, including Snoopy fighting his infamous rival the Red Baron. I thought this film paid homage to Charles Schulz' comic fairly well. All of the nuances of the characters are captured, from Lucy's psychiatric booth to Linus and his blanket. It paints an accurate picture of what made The Charlie Brown and Snoopy show so legendary. I enjoyed this film and thought it was a fitting tribute ----------------------------------------------------------------------- B
The best Movie I've seen in years. 100% Schulz.

Horribly Boring movie....... zzzzzz

Met with much skepticism since its announcement, Blue Sky Studios' "The Peanuts Movie" is happily yet another clever and fun hit from the animation company who has had some real good films with Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who and Rio, some real misses like Robots and Epic, and of course the Ice Age movies which REALLY vary based on taste and which move you're talking about. Much like Horton Hears a Who before it, this film offers a beautifully-animated take on the classic characters and world, giving us a simple tale of Charlie Brown's life and Snoopy's adventures through span of half a year, in a time where most animated movies have big epic stories and probably WAY too many ideas, and respectfully honors Charles M. Schulz's work and the wonderful Peanuts specials that came beforehand, thanks in no small part to Steve Martino's skilled direction and being written and produced by members of the Schulz family. Take it from me: The Peanuts Movie is one welcoming trip into a nostalgic realm that still relates to people even to this day and is well worth checking out for some good times.

Stays very true to the comic strips and offers a type of animation that is very innovative for movie goers. Peanuts is great and Charlie Brown might be the most lovable character ever in animation. I grew up with Snoopy and the gang and this movie was everything I wanted, and more. The animation may be updated but the heart of the movie is still old school Peanuts. They still use land lines and typewriters, and write book reports with paper and pencil. There is no rap video and Lucy still charges a nickel. Rating: Fetching (I am making it happen Regina) This movie does it's job of taking the classic characters and bringing them to our modern theaters in a charming way. I did not remember how much I knew about the Peanuts until I was sitting in the auditorium but I recalled quite a bit that only enhanced the experience. The story is a brilliant blend of the underdog striving to achieve success in Charlie Brown and the friendship that surrounds him, especially with Snoopy. Speaking of which that dog pretty much steals the show for me with his unpredictable humor and undying loyalty to Charlie. Snoopy also presents a minor flaw in the movie with the Red Baron stuff included. I personally thought most of it was well handled, but at times it felt distracting from the main throughpoint. Also since this is a family movie some of the jokes naturally don't hit for me as an adult, but none were juvenile like some other animation movies recently *cough cough* Minions. Overall I would say that you have any desire to see this movie, or just enjoy a good family film with heart check this out.
The Peanuts Movie offers great memories to the times of the peanuts episodes. It shows that the peanuts arent finished yet.
I love this movie. It manages to capture all of the heart that the comic strip and specials had. This had me smiling practically the whole way through, and I'm sure it'll get an Oscar nomination.

As someone who had previously had only a passing familiarity with the source material, I am impressed at how the Peanuts Movie still feels like a truly spectacular piece of animation. There is a beauty to the cg animation which seeks to emulate the original 2D animation. I loved the exaggerated expressions. The story is built around a formula of impressing the girl, using it to be able to concentrate on clever ways to arrive at the conclusions which any adult will see coming. We know Charlie Brown must fail. However, you are unlikely to figure out ahead of time how this happens. The jokes don't constantly hit (through the little kids will find this movie especially funny) but the hits will hit you hard enough that you won't be able to recover until it hits you again. This is the kind of adaptation that will get your kids interested and remind you of why you loved Peanuts in the first place.

I dreaded this thing when it was announced. I only went to the theater due to the interesting animation style... the way Schulz's iconic linework was kept in tact in a 3D environment. Still, the trailer made me trepidatious, content-wise. (I like very little non Disney/Pixar American animation, anyway.) Turns out...this is a wonderful little movie. Despite the occasional intrusion of modern music, and a light over-reliance of slapstick, the thing is funny in the way the comic strips and old moves/ TV specials were. That is to say... it has a sardonic, wry, bleak little heart beneath its colorful exterior. The moments of warmpth are hard-earned, and even they are undercut with meloncholy. This movie honors the amazing cartoonist who invented these characters, & I'm happy it's making bank, 'cuz I'd gladly see another.

What's a prematurely balding blockhead to do when his dog fancies himself a WWI flying ace, all the adults sound like muted trombones, and he's got an unrequited crush on the redhead who's moved in across the street? Enjoyable adaptation of Charles Schulz's long-running comic strip is entertaining enough for grown-ups, but personally I could've done with much less of Snoopy flying around on his doghouse - the kids were far more interesting and engaging, and the voice talent was good too.

Not much to say on this one. It does suffer from many of the problems other Blue Sky productions have, such as an excess of movement instead of just letting a slower moment play out, but even with that most of the charm of Schultz' strip comes through. I don't see this replacing the TV specials, but for what it is - a typically Charlie Brown underdog story with a heap of Snoopy thrown in - I can't fault it, and it certainly made me smile more than once. So I went and saw the Peanuts Movie yesterday. It was really awesome. I grew up from the cradle with Snoopy and the Peanuts gang (my Mom and Dad still have the headboard with Snoopy from my cradle as a baby) and had all the movies as a kid. What struck me most about this movie is how untouched by cynicism it was. It was "Peanuts" through-and-through. When Charlie Brown was talking on the phone, it was a two-piece phone with a cord. Snoopy typed on a typewriter, not a laptop. The gang weren't tapping away on tablets or anything like that. And I loved the lesson - he might not succeed, but Charlie Brown NEVER gives up and ALWAYS does the right thing. This was "Peanuts" through-and-through.
The plot isn't terribly strong; however the movie is charming. While the movie at least feels like Charlie Brown. Which you can't say about most recent adaptations of classic cartoons.
A near perfect big screen adaptation of the timeless comic strip and television specials. It's awesome!

The Peanuts Movie is a funny, sweet, heartfelt and enormously charming big screen revival of Charles Shulz's beloved creations, one that does justice to the the look, feel and spirit of the comics and TV specials of yore. To say that this is Blue Sky Animation's best film to date is an understatement (not a high bar to clear, but still), precisely because it avoids any pressures to try and modernize itself or compromise what it is, instead telling a simple, universally relatable story that gives the film more of a timeless quality. While the die-hard Peanuts fan in me wouldn't have minded a few more darker or bittersweet touches of the kind you'd see from the earlier comics and TV specials, it generally finds a nice middle ground that balances capturing childhood's disappointments and cruel twists of fate with the small victories and sources of solace that make it all feel worthwhile.
This is such a charming, funny and genuine time! It respects the older Peanuts specials perfectly.
there were some funny parts but the whole movie was boring! worst $15 i spent on a ticket

Tastefully done with care and ease, "The Pleanuts Movie" brings back the classic characters in all of the ways you hoped they would. The central story is that there is a new girl at school that Charlie Brown is gushing over and does not have the guts to speak to her. Side plots include a 3D look into what snoopy has been fighting all these years and Charlie Brown trying to win a talent show to impress this new mystery girl. I loved every aspect on how they mixed the old school two dimensional style animation with the new school 3D. It was done carefully and the callbacks to the original specials were done perfectly. Although it does rely on some of the source material to drive the story, I was able to look past that and see that they were just trying to pay homage. "The Peanuts Movie" will put a smile on your face no matter when you watch it. It is the children's feel-good film of the year. Is it one of the best animated films I've seen in a long time? Of course not! It is an extremely fun family film with great laughs, a heartwarming story for kids, and great messages throughout. This film may borrow a lot of elements from the past, but it is still great. This film was a pleasure to watch!

"Good grief Blue Sky Studios, you blockheads really messed with a beloved American icon!" That is what I would say if The Peanuts Movie was a bad movie. But it is not. True, it feels lengthy and stretched; Like butter over too much bread. That's only because I'm used to these things being resolved in 30 minutes with commercials throughout, but that aside, this is a loving adaptation of the Peanuts characters, and here's why: We start with a snow day declared. Charlie Brown's little sister Lucy answering the phone call of Miss Othmar (Troy "Trombone Shorty" Andrews and his classic trombone sound for all the adults) that there's a snow-day! The other kids get this call, and winter fun begins for the Peanuts gang: Peppermint Patty, Marcy, Franklin, Linus and Lucy Van Pelt, Pig-Pen, and all the other characters you grew up with on those annual ABC reruns that have surpassed 50 years! (Fun fact: This year is the 50th anniversary of Merry Christmas Charlie Brown and the 65th anniversary of the original comic strips. Coincidence?) Following that, Charlie Brown is called out to play, and after getting himself together, he brings out: A kite? Good grief, it's one of those movies, where a kid feels hopelessly outmatched by the world, he wants to get the girl, but doesn't have the guts... Well, it goes in that direction after the Little Red-Haired Girl moves across the street from him, but with the help of his trusty dog Snoopy (Voiced through archive recordings by Bill Melendez, the original Snoopy sound effects) they embark on a quest to make Charlie Brown more confident. Along the way, we also see Snoopy write a story about a dog fighting the Red Baron (Sound familiar?) and both stories parallel each other splendidly: Charlie Brown's story inspires the story-within-a-story, bringing in more classic Peanuts without making it a cess-pool of hashed-together imagery of Peanuts. Whether you're eight or 80, you won't be able to help feeling for Charlie Brown, and maybe sympathize with him. The animation may seem odd at first, but that aside, it is a beautiful CGI rendering of the world of Peanuts that feels like one you could reach out and touch (Helps if you see it in 3D) and stays true to the cartoon visuals of the 60s specials and the comic strips. No new characters are introduced, and thankfully, celebrity voices are not forced into the roles of the characters, which avoids distractions of "Do I know this voice?" like Citizen Kane managed to do. Christoph Beck provides a great soundtrack to the main story, but don't think that songs meant to help market this movie and some of the Vince Guaraldi music didn't find their way in: The winter dance scene has modern music that seems out of place in a 60s-esque school, but because the Vince Guaraldi music was placed so well, I grant it a pardon: Every timeless tale and beloved character need some kind of twist here and there, or else this would not be a loving tribute, but a rehash of the same old thing. With a fresh new story of Charlie Brown trying to become more confident in visuals that stay true to the source material in a day-and-age of computers, and a cast of actors we won't remember, but who fill the shoes of the original voice actors of the Peanuts TV specials, The Peanuts Movie does not deserve to be slugged by the audience or critics, but to be praised. Those were no blockheads in the studio: Just good people doing the right thing.

Rating: 9/10Having grown up with all the animated TV series of Charlie Brown and Snoopy during my childhood, I can say without a doubt that "The Peanuts Movie" perfectly respects the spirit of the universe and the classic characters created by Charles Schulz. Even if nothing new or ambitious was attempted in it, it still is a very well made and fantastically sweet and charming animated movie. I was very pleased by it and impressed how they managed to convert the 2D world created by Charles Schulz into a 3D world while respecting all the design, details and structure of the characters and elements which are part of this classic world.This movie will please adults as myself who grew up with the classic world of Charlie Brown and Snoopy, but also a new generation of children who will be introduced to it thanks to this film.

I thought the plot was too scattered and disjointed, while they tried to stuff a reference to every major Peanuts event into the movie when it wasn't necessary. However, I still love the animation style used for the movie, especially little touches like showing the characters' memories as 2D comic-style drawings. The voice actors they chose for the characters were also spot-on.

The story can be a bit jagged at times, with a somewhat important plot element that's seemingly instantly dropped for no reason; yet it doesn't change the countless smiles that will be put on your face. The Peanuts Movie is a love letter (in the best possible way) to the classic comic strip, and just a fun movie overall.

Schlemiel: (Yiddish) a stupid, awkward, or unlucky person.Charlie Brown is a 'schlemiel. I realized that today watching this through my adult eyes. Charlie Brown is a hapless, self-absorbed, worrisome 'schlep' of a guy who is constantly stuck in existential mode, obsessing over social status and wallowing in self pity. His dog Snoopy, is his Superego. His sister Sally represents the sweetly blissful ignorance that Charles lost the day he became 'self aware' lol.His circle of friends represent people who have an identity in life - everything he is NOT but wishes to be: an accomplished pianist prodigy (Schroeder); a doting motherly older sibling (Lucy); a philosophizing best friend (Linus); a carefree loafer (pigpen); an athletic tomboy (Peppermint Patty), and her faithfully ever-present sidekick (Marcie). Even his dog Snoopy, represents a guy with a certain 'saviore-faire' aloofness, a canine version of Walter Mitty, happily playing out his fantasies with such detached cool that he remained the sole source of entertainment in this animation about pre-life crisis lolI know I'm making this review sound bizarre, but when Schulz wrote Charlie Brown he really brought in some SERIOUS SHIT. This kid has a lot of life baggage at the tender age of 10. If he doesn't get some real help - more than 5 cents worth lol - this will not turn out good.We basically spend an hour and 20min watching a kid obsess over and stalk a girl for an entire school year. If this animation took place in today's world (sadly, it does not) - Charlie Brown would be a Facebook stalker. In today's world that shit is disturbing. I'm pretty sure the producers WISELY decided to keep the story retro...Trust me, they knew that the source material is some heavy shit. It would take a surprisingly disturbing turn on social media, cellphones, snapchats, and texts lolBut, the oddly deep emotional element is EXACTLY what I found so funny about watching Peanuts! :D :D As a child I laughed at the colorful antics - mainly Snoopy. But as an adult I was sitting there thinking 'Damn... this kid has it BAD.' lmaoIMO, as a guy who grew up reading THOUSANDS of Peanuts comic strips and watching every animation made, I was personally disappointed that the source material was not updated and modernized. This movie was basically a re-hash of every Peanuts joke we'd already seen as kids. :-/On another note, I'd LOVE to see a new version of Peanuts where we can witness how they all turn out. :D
The movie is great but the biggest flaw is that the pain toward Charlie Brown is too much even for haters.
