This is such a great movie. I thoroughly enjoyed everything about it. The story stays 100% true to the comics and TV specials, thanks in most part to the excellent writing of Charles Shultz's son and grandson. Add to the fact that the animation staff tirelessly researched and studied Shultz's drawing style down to a T, in order to bring us the most authentic visual style of Mr. Shultz. You almost forget that what you are watching is CGI animation and not traditional hand drawn animation. Even though this is CG, there are also wonderful artistic touches the animators threw in, from the detail of Snoopy's fur and the tuft of fur at the back of Fifi's head to the ambiance of the clouds and the buildings. Plus, when you throw in a director who is such a big fan of the comic (who can also draw the Peanuts gang flawlessly), you really can't go wrong.The critics who have rated this movie as rotten, truly miss the point of the movie entirely. There is no malice, potty humor, or any other "children's animation" trope that is so prevalent in today's children's fare. This movie is sincere, funny, touching, and at times emotional. It's probably one of the only movies this year that is good, 100% clean fun for children, adults and fans alike. Go see this movie.
If you are a true Peanuts fan, you will love the movie. The animation is tremendous and does Charles Schulz justice.

A very charming adaptation that is more faithful to the the early television specials than it is to the strip. The producers were smart to refrain from modernizing the storyline or characters and keep it timeless. There are no cell phones, video games or pop references. Most of the story is lifted from the strips and specials of the mid to late sixties when Shultz was in top form. It was nice to see them bring back characters that were long retired, like Frieda and Shermy. I was also pleased that there was plenty of Vince Guaraldi music. My only complaint is that the Snoopy vs. The Red Baron scenes were overly long and too frequent. If you loved the classic Peanuts, I'm sure you'll enjoy this film.

As delightful as any Peanuts Gang show! No matter how familiar we are to the story of Charlie Brown and the Little Red-Haired Girl, Snoopy as the Flying Ace versus the Red Baron, or as Joe Cool, Linus and Sally, Lucy and Schroeder, Peppermint Patty and Marcie, Violet, Patty and Lucy (a.k.a. the original Mean Girls), Shermy and his dance moves, and the rest of the adorable timeless characters, the whole gang never fails to entertain and put big smiles on people's faces. Snoopy and his crazy antics didn't disappoint. He had me laughing. I already knew he was going after Linus' blanket, drag Linus, and cause a riot in the process, and yet it is still funny as ever. At one point, however, I thought I'd never see the Flying Ace have a pint of root beer. I anxiously waited and waited to the near point of giving up that the filmmakers didn't include it. To my surprise, root beer for the Flying Ace and even for every one of Snoopy's siblings! That was great surprise to have them make an appearance (sorry if that was a spoiler alert, but it's not like anyone else was thinking when the Flying Ace would get to have his root beer or expect to see his siblings in the movie -- I know I was). Overall, a delightful movie, one that I would see over and over again like all the classics. Well done!

Reviewers who give this anything less than 4 stars are really missing the point. There was obviously much thought put into NOT modernizing this classic. The two things they modernize (standardized testing & Little Red-Haired Girl speaking) were intentional. For a lifelong Peanuts comic lover, this movie is perfection. If it fails to infuse a children's movie with adult humor and fleeting mass media references, that only serves to make it a classic alongside its source material. Bravo Schultz family for not allowing Hollywood to tarnish the shine of the existentialism that makes Peanuts a comic strip with few peers.

After 65 years for the launched of the most popular comic strip, 50 years since the airing of a television special and 35 years since their last theatrical film! Charlie Brown, Snoopy and the rest of the Peanuts gang have finally made on the big screen! From the Original Creator, Charles M Schulz to Producer Paul Feig (Heavy Weights, Bridemaids & Spy) and Schulz's Wife, Jean and two sons, Craig and Bryan. With the help of "Blue Sky" Animation and Director, Steve Martino (Horton Hears A Who!) that brought the 3-D CGI Animation, a quality realistic Stop-Motion capture to life! It's been a long time since Charlie Brown, Snoopy, Linus, and the rest of the Peanuts gang ruled on the TV and movie screens, and in this age full of bad Disney Channel kid-coms, smart-alecky "geared for kids" humor on Nickelodeon, and the fart jokes and toilet humor shoved down our throats by feature animation studios that aren't Pixar and Disney, is there anymore room for the Peanuts gang? The answer is a proud yes. I'm happy to say that this film is an absolute love-letter to Charles M. Schulz and his beloved Peanuts comic strip, which lasted for over 50 years between 1950 and 2000.The film begins with a snow day, school is cancelled that day, and we see the whole gang with all their personalities from the strip intact. Charlie Brown, played by child actor Noah Schnapp (who played the young son in Steven Spielberg's recent Bridge of Spies), is on a mission to get the attention of her instant crush, the Little Red Haired Girl, while on a side plot - Snoopy is on a mission as the World War I Flying Ace to defeat the Red Baron and save her damsel in distress, Fifi (played by Broadway star Kristin Chenoweth). The latter lowers the bar a little, but I had to admit, they fit the 3D in the film. However, when I saw the ending scene with Charlie Brown and the Little Red Haired Girl finally meeting for the first time, and the latter telling the former she likes him for who she is, I was a 24-year-old man crying his eyes out, and I never cry during movies.As Charlie Brown, Schnapp sounds exactly like Peter Robbins did in the 1965 special A Charlie Brown Christmas, as do all the other children playing characters such as Lucy, Linus, Franklin, Peppermint Patty (played by teen actress Venus Schultheis), and Marcie. Through the magic of archival recordings, Snoopy's role is reprised by the late animator Bill Melendez, who produced the animated Peanuts specials throughout the 1960's-2000's, The Little Red Haired Girl is played by Francis Capaldi, who also stars in Disney Channel's atrocious sitcom Dog with a Blog. She's proved to be a pretty good actress too. This is not like other movies based on an established properties, such as the horrendous Alvin and the Chipmunks films or the even worse Smurfs series (which thankfully is getting an all-animated reboot 2 years from now), this is a faithful, ambitious tribute to Charles Schulz's original comic strip, a nostalgic trip back in time. And even if some of my fellow critics decided politicize the film (like how Variety's Peter Debruge decided to inject race into the movie), it will still be a movie that both kids and adults can enjoy this November.

Thank God for Snoopy and his little pal Woodstock. Without them, this fiasco of an homage to the legacy of Charles Schulz - brought to the big screen in part by Schulz's son, Craig, and grandson, Bryan - would be irredeemably dull and without purpose. As it is, the film still lacks a raison d'�tre beyond the mercenary, and only the prospect of seeing Snoopy chase the Red Baron once more, Woodstock in tow, should motivate anyone to see it. For my money, if you want a decent cinematic adaptation of the adventures of Charlie Brown and his faithful canine companion, watch�"Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit"�again. Better yet, check out the "Peanuts" TV shows�of yore, referenced throughout this new film (slow plot moment? cue Vince Guaraldi). All we get here is stale recycling of old plot lines, now rendered in 3D. Sadly, this brief review is all the movie deserves.

A worry going in to The Peanuts Movie was simply this: in 2015, in a time where animation is all computer-animated and with super-sophistication but also lacking the sort of approach that came with the simple, quirky, edgy-but-cute style of the Peanuts cartoons from the past half century, how do you bring that world out and make it feel right? And there was an element of the story that made me raise an eyebrow, and reminded me of an issue I had with the recent 2011 return of The Muppets - a new character comes to the universe of the Peanuts. Would this character fit in? Would it be distracting if he or she looks different or acts un-Peanuts-like? And what does Peanuts-like mean, you might ask, by the way? It's that thing where, simply, kids think like kids, but with an extra level of sophistication in the writing. Let me put it this way: The Peanuts Movie is the only movie that kids will see which has a reference to Tolstoy's War and Peace (though it's not initially called that by Peppermint Patty).But fears are assuaged as I return from seeing the movie and find the movie is very successful at what it aims to be. In short, this is at its best... just another Peanuts movie, but that's a sincere compliment. You watch some of those movies and specials, which have stood the test of time due to the wit of the writing and the beautiful (yes, beautiful) animation that does simply to bring Charles Schulz's comic to life, and those shows and movies (i.e. the best, A Boy Named Charlie Brown, but also Snoopy Come Home and Bon Voyage, Charlie Brown) with issues that kids deal with, whether or not they directly relate to the hero. In this story it's all about this new girl coming to school (we never learn her name, there's really no need to), and how good old Chuck can barely deal with his ridiculously nervous reaction. How can he even say hello to her, much less carry a conversation? What can he do to build up his confidence? Can Lucy with her Nickel-store advice and 10-step book help? Can he become a success in some way?Whether you're coming to this as someone who has been watching Peanuts all your life, or if you have a little kid (or are one) and have never seen one of these and it's your introduction, it is a wholly delightful experience. Schulz's kids were co-screenwriters, which could have been great or not-so-great (one never knows if the purity will work or become too stifling, or if there are too many attempts to make it "hip" and "Modern", which means it won't age so well years down the line). All of the Peanuts characters we know and like are here - I couldn't find one major one who wasn't, and everyone gets a moment or two (I even forgot for a moment Lucy's crush for Schroeder, but it's here too). And of course Snoopy as the super rascal/charmer/adventurer of the lot who tries to do things like sneak into school as a teacher ("No dogs allowed!" duh) and spends his part time writing stories about being an ace pilot with the "Red Baron" plane.With the exception of a couple of elements that, frankly, I could've taken or left, like some of the Red Baron bits (some are OK, some may drag unless you're a kid into the action-loaded visuals), and the inclusion of a couple of pop songs (not annoying ones, but they are of this time period) and a lack (not completely, but not enough) of Vince Guaraldi's irreplaceable jazz score, the movie really works. I cared about Charlie Brown on his journey through building up his confidence, through ups and downs that were not, and occasionally were, his fault. And along the whole way, there's that special thing that made Peanuts work, has always made it work, and will continue for many years to come: you want to see this guy win, and yet it's funnier/more realistic when he falls on his face. But maybe every Charlie Brown has his day in this case? Between the talent show, school dance, book report, summer pen-pal deal, can Charlie Brown say ONE word to this girl? Who knows.They're all here and its spirit is pure. What else do you need to know? The Peanuts Movie is a blast of family entertainment in the young and old sense of the word, full of clever lines and visual-eye-pleasing slapstick and, (happy surprise) pathos.

I'm glad Peanuts is getting the attention, but this is not Peanuts to me. The 3D destroys much of what I love about the original (the simplicity of the drawings, the uncluttered backgrounds, the oil colors of the movies and oldest specials etc.). This is like going to watch a stage production of "A Boy Named Charlie Brown" but even then...Part of what made the previous Peanuts movies and specials so accessible is that they didn't try to be self-contained presentations but merely "just another chapter" in the world of these characters, an extension of the comics. You could watch them in any order, repeatedly, and they would feel just as fresh and inviting, like catching an old episode of Andy Griffith or The Lone Ranger. This movie is designed to stand alone, to be Peanuts for a world in which the daily strip is no longer being produced.My son will want to see it and he will love it and that's fine. But it would appear that, for me at least, Peanuts is over.

The Peanuts Movie is for family and children young and old for all ages, everyone's most beloved and kind-hearted blockhead Charlie Brown tries to impress the beautiful little red-haired girl, and everyone's lovable beagle Snoopy meets his nemesis, and goes against it. This is one of the films that young and olds will watch again and again. And it's filled with charming characters, harmless jokes, and it's warm-heartedly animated. This movie is a must see film, especially for those who love Charlie Brown and The Peanuts.
